author: John Csiszar
title: Want To Be a Millionaire? Embrace These 13 Habits Now
text:
Want To Be a Millionaire? Embrace These 13 Habits Now
One million dollars is a number that many people set as a target for their
retirement nest egg, and it has something of a mythical feel about it. The very idea of being a millionaire symbolizes great wealth for most Americans, and indeed only about 8.8% of Americans actually are millionaires, putting them in the category of the financial elite.
However, there are concrete steps that anyone can take to increase their chances of reaching a seven-digit net worth. By starting early enough and implementing some of these financial steps, you may find yourself in this rarefied company
more easily than you think.
Start Investing Early
Probably the single biggest step you can take towards achieving millionaire status is to start investing early. As Mark Cuban said, “When investing, the best thing you can do is start early.” Socking away as little as $200 per month when you are 20 can translate to over $1 million by age 65 if you earn an 8% return on your investments. While no investment return is guaranteed, the long-term average return of the S&P 500 index easily eclipses this 8% target. However, as billionaire Warren Buffet advised: “The best time to plant a tree was 20 years ago. The second-best time is now.” So, better to start now than not at all.
Save Until It Hurts
You might have heard that you should save at least 10% of your income to generate long-term wealth. While that’s a great start, if you want to
become a millionaire, you’ll have to save until it hurts. This means different things for different people. If you’re only earning $25,000 per year, saving 10% of your money might hurt a little — but try pushing it to 15% or 20%. If you earn $200,000 per year, you might be able to push that savings rate to 50% or more. Or, to put it simply, listen to Buffet: “Do not save what is left after spending; spend what is left after saving.”
Invest in Appreciating Assets, Not Depreciating Ones
One of the most important steps in reaching millionaire status is to only put your money into investments that will generate a positive return for you. In plain English, this means you should be investing in assets that have demonstrated long-term earnings potential, like the stock market and real estate, not in assets that lose value every day, like new cars or consumer goods.
Continually Increase Your Income
The cost of living goes up nearly every year, so if your income doesn’t grow as well, you’ll never generate true wealth. Regularly ask for raises at your job so your income rises faster than the inflation rate. If you can’t squeeze any more money out of your current job, consider taking on a side gig or some type of additional work so you can continue to raise your income.
Generate Passive Income
Millionaires and billionaires agree: Passive income is incredibly important to amassing a fortune. As Buffet said, “If you don’t find a way to make money while you sleep, you will work until you die,” It’s hard to get wealthy just from earning a salary. But you can get to millionaire status a lot more quickly if you generate income that you don’t have to work for, known as passive income. A classic example is rental income. Once you buy a rental property, you’ll get paid every month by your renters without having to do any additional work beyond routine maintenance and repairs. If your rental income exceeds the amount you pay for your mortgage, property tax and other costs, you’re essentially using other people’s money to pay for your property while you sit and watch its value increase. Be like investor and author Robert Kiyosaki, who said, “my passive income exceeds my expenses. That’s financial independence.”
Pay Off Credit Card Debt
Knocking down your credit card balances won’t earn you any money, but it might still be the best “investment” you ever make. If you carry a balance on your credit card, you may be paying interest of 20% or more annually. No investment you make can reliably generate those types of returns, so paying off any outstanding balances you have is one of the best possible uses of your money.
Maximize Your 401(k) Match
If you’re lucky enough to have a 401(k) match at your job, you absolutely must take advantage of it each and every year. A 401(k) match may be the closest thing to free money you’ll ever receive, and best of all, it’s deposited into a tax-advantaged investment account. Even if you can’t contribute the absolute maximum to your 401(k) every year, at least contribute enough to claim your full employer match.
Maintain a Top-Tier Credit Score
As financial guru
Suze Orman said, “A good credit score is better than money.” A top-tier credit score won’t put any money in your pocket directly, but it can save you literally tens of thousands of dollars over your lifetime, perhaps even more. With a credit score above 740, you can usually qualify for the lowest available interest rates on everything from home mortgages to auto loans, and the savings can really pile up. A $300,000, 30-year mortgage at 3.0% vs. 4.5%, for example, will save you over $74,000 in interest over the life of the loan.
Live in an Affordable Community
America is a vast country with plenty of comfortable places to live. If you can live in a lower-cost area while still earning the same salary, it’s the same as if you got a significant raise. As more and more companies are allowing their employees to work remotely, see if you can move to a less-expensive area and boost your savings rate to help you achieve millionaire status.
Be Entrepreneurial and Take Calculated Risks
“The only limit to our realization of tomorrow will be our doubts of today,” said U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt. Millionaires are often willing to take smart risks to grow their money through new business ventures. Calculated risks and entrepreneurship can lead to greater reward.
Network and Seek Mentorship
Surrounding yourself with knowledgeable peers and mentors accelerates learning and unlocks opportunities. As Shark Tank’s Daymond John said,”Finding mentors has been key to my success.” Millionaires invest time in networking and mentor relationships.
Learn Constantly and Improve Your Skills
“Risk comes from not knowing what you’re doing,” said Buffett. Education and skill development are lifelong pursuits. Millionaires continually learn to expand their knowledge, abilities and opportunities.
Practice Intentional Goal Setting
Millionaires set clear goals for their money and review them regularly. Intentional goal setting and tracking progress are keys to success. “Decide what you want, decide what you are willing to exchange for it. Establish your priorities and go to work,” said American tycoon H. L. Hunt.
Laura Beck contributed to the reporting for this article.

author: @BBCSport
title: Monaghan GAA: Bannigan appointed as manager of Farney county - BBC Sport
text:
Gabriel Bannigan has been confirmed as the new manager of Monaghan, succeeding former Farney boss Vinny Corey, who relinquished the position in August after two seasons at the helm.
Former Leitrim manager Andy Moran, John McElhone and Damien Freeman will form his backroom team.
Bannigan spent two seasons as a selector during Corey's time in charge.
"Monaghan GAA is delighted to announce that Aughnamullen native Gabriel Bannigan was formally ratified as Senior Football Manager by Monaghan County Committee at a meeting earlier this evening," read a statement released by Monaghan GAA on Thursday evening.
"Gabriel will be joined by Andy Moran, John McElhone and Damien Freeman and has been appointed for a three-year term with a review after two years.
"Best wishes to Gabriel and his backroom team."
Corey stepped down from the role in August after an indifferent campaign which included relegation from Division One of the Allianz League, an Ulster Championship exit at the hands of Cavan in the preliminary round and defeat by Galway in the preliminary quarter-finals of the All-Ireland Series after advancing from the group stage.
Bannigan's coaching career has included spells working with Dublin clubs Kilmacud Crokes and St Sylvester's and with his home club Aughnamullen, whom he took from junior to senior football within three seasons in Monaghan.
Related topics Gaelic Games Northern Ireland Sport

author: @fox5vegas
title: Family reunited with photo album that washed away in Helene floodwaters
text:
A North Carolina family has been reunited with a photo album that had been washed away in the floodwaters during Helene. (WXII, SHAWN VESTEY, CNN) By Kara Peters, WXII via CNN Newsource Published: Oct. 11, 2024 at 4:14 AM PDT | Updated: 2 hours ago Email This Link
Share on Facebook
Share on X (formerly Twitter)
Share on Pinterest
Share on LinkedIn
HICKORY, N.C. (WXII) - A good Samaritan returned to his hometown of Boone, North Carolina, to help with the cleanup from Helene.
What he found within the mud and debris ended up being valuable and irreplaceable for one family.
The saying goes, “A picture is worth a thousand words,” but no words can describe the moment Brittany Wilson met the good Samaritan that found her family’s photo album filled with childhood memories.
“Sadness, but happiness,” Wilson remarked. “I see my family. There’s my mom and my cousins and everything, you know, my great-grandma. I miss her dearly. I was 19 when I lost her, but I do thank you.”
Shawn Vestey went up to his hometown a week ago to help with the cleanup from Helene only to find so much more within the mud and debris.
“It was kind of devastating because I didn’t know if it was the people we were right beside because there was a house right beside it, or I didn’t know if it was upstream,” Vestey said. “My first thought was I need to post this and find the owner because I knew somebody would probably want these photos back.”
Vestey then posted the missing photo album on Facebook, and within hours, he received a response.
“I’m just scrolling through Facebook and I had to stop for a minute because my heart sank,” Wilson said. “I seen my great-grandmother in one and I’m like, ‘There’s no way.’"
Wilson and Vestey met for the first time in Hickory to reflect on the photo album that swept through the waters of Helene.
The pages and crinkled pictures now add a whole new perspective.
“My aunt and uncle lost their whole shop, and it even went into their home and flooded their home, too,” Wilson added. “Obviously, they still can’t even find their shed that just completely washed away.”
The unexpected reunion served as a reminder that even in the midst of devastation, there are still moments to be grateful.
“It warmed my heart knowing that a complete stranger, that all he had to do was to throw them away. I mean, he had no connection to my family’s photos, could just post that and take the time out to do that, so I really do appreciate that,” Wilson said.
The story does not stop there.
Wilson says another stranger found even more photos of her family after the storm. She plans to connect with that good Samaritan soon to retrieve those.
“It gives you kind of hope and purpose in a way, which is nice,” Vestey said.
Copyright 2024 WXII via CNN Newsource. All rights reserved.

author: About Abdullahim Admin
title: Federation Cup: Akwa United, Insurance, Enyimba, others zoom to round of 32 - Blueprint Newspapers Limited
text:
Former champions Akwa United, Rivers United, Bendel Insurance and Enyimba Wednesday advanced to the Round of 32 of the President’s Federation Cup played across various venues in the country.
The Round of 64 matches, which started on Tuesday, continued with no noticeable upset usually associated with the FA Cup.
Bendel Insurance, winners of the cup in 2023, thumped Dandidi Babes 5-0 to reach the next round. Similarly, Enyimba also whitewashed El-Shama 5-0 at the Lafia Township Stadium. Ekene Awazie (brace), Mujeeb Odufeso, and Chidiebere Nnachi (brace) scored in the one-sided encounter.
In Abuja, Rivers United edged Barau FC 2-1 to reach the next round, while 2017 winners Akwa United also beat Kebbi United by the same scoreline at the Bwari Township Stadium.
Another NPFL side Sunshine Stars also beat Bako FC 2-0 to secure their place in the next round of the competition. Similarly, Lobi Stars claimed a 2-0 win over Discovery Talent to progress to Round of 32.
Katsina United edged Green Beret 1-0 at the Sani Abacha Stadium in Kano, FC Basira breezed past Atlantic FA 5-0, and former finalists Nasarawa United beat Flight FC 2-0.
Defending champions Elkanemi Warriors also edged Simon Ben FC 3-2 in a tight affair to march on.
Matches involving Shooting Stars and Bayelsa were not played after their opponents EFCC and Zamfara United failed to show up. The two sides have now moved into the next round without kicking a ball.

author: Ubah Ali
title: Team that recovers items that fall through lake ice sees increase in calls during warm winter - CBS Minnesota
text:
DETROIT LAKES, Minn. — Our warm winter is creating dangerous conditions on our lakes, no matter how far north you go.
Many of the ice houses that were already set up are going down.
It's keeping a specialized team of Minnesotans busy.
Tri-State Diving in Detroit Lakes deep dive to bring back what's been lost or fallen through the ice. Gary Thompson and his team are folks that pull it back up.
RELATED: December 2023 is tracking to be warmest on record in Minnesota
"Right now, I'm telling people if you have a fish house on the lake, get it off it's going to end up down," Thompson said.
The lack of ice triggered a new state-wide warning from the Minnesota Department of Natural Resources.
"It'll take a while several consecutive days for the ice to form a new clear layer underneath and people need to wait and be patient for that," said Nicole Biagi, Department of Natural Resources, Ice Safety Coordinator.
It has caused some bizarre scenes across our 10,000 lakes: A plane sticking out of Upper Red Lake or an after-Christmas water skier in Maple Grove.
Thompson sighed heavily and said it's not a normal year.
During a normal winter, he says they do about one recovery a week.
"Since Christmas Eve, I've had 13 calls come in and recover," Thompson said.
Last week, his team went out to Crystal Lake where a 4-wheeler plunged in. In Little Cormorant Lake near Detroit Lakes, a fish house broke through the ice.
READ MORE: Lack of snow, ice partially to blame for warmer winter temperatures in Minnesota
"We put sleds on the wheels of the fish house and rolled it onto shore," Thompson said. "We pull it for 500 yards to get it out."
Ice conditions can also be dangerous for experts. Thompson said during a recovery Wednesday, his team could see the ice cracking around them.
The lack of ice is changing how many Minnesotans enjoy the winter outdoors.

author: Ahmed Jallow
title: Cooper approves bill that preserves, updates automatic expunction law
text:
Gov. Roy Cooper signed legislation that will preserve and update the state's automatic expunction law, which is deigned to aid people with certain criminal records in overcoming barriers to employment and housing. (Photo: Clayton Henkel)
A debate over a state law that governs the expunction of criminal records was resolved quickly and quietly before state lawmakers left town in late June, allowing automatic expunctions to resume on July 1 for certain “dismissed” or “not guilty” verdicts.
On Monday, Gov. Roy Cooper signed a measure ( Senate Bill 565 ) that makes revisions to the statute, but the bill no longer contained a provision that had been included that would have repealed the law.
“At first, the purpose of Senate Bill 565 was to restart automatic expungement with some needed fixes,” said Laura Webb, Director of the North Carolina Justice Center’s Fair Chance project. “And then what happened … was the bill basically was gutted and rewritten to repeal automatic expungement.”
“This sparked a significant effort, with many people coming forward to fight the repeal,” said Webb.
The story of the expunction law has been a case of good intentions running up against real world logistical challenges.
In December 2021, North Carolina became the 14th state to automatically expunge criminal charges resulting in acquittals or dismissals, removing the need for individuals to file petitions to delete these charges from their records.
The changes were part of a broader ‘second chance’ movement in North Carolina and nationwide that seeks to allow people with certain criminal records to overcome barriers to employment and housing.
But nine months after the law was enacted, in August 2022, lawmakers suspended it temporarily after the court system became overwhelmed by the volume of records it was being required to expunge. The legislature directed the courts to create a group to recommend fixes for the problem which included handling and retaining records confidentially.
The resumption of the law, delayed twice, was due to take effect this July 1. But in May, some lawmakers attempted to repeal automatic expunction entirely, sparking the backlash from advocates.
In late June, a conference committee report for the legislation emerged that discarded the repeal and both houses unanimously approved the revised version on June 26.
“Without automation, most people who are eligible to get their charges expunged won’t do that just because they don’t know how to, and so the backlog of eligible cases just kind of illustrates that,” said Webb.
Advocates say several factors contribute to this, including the complexity of navigating the criminal process, lack of awareness of the program, complicated eligibility criteria, and financial barriers.
Before automatic expunctions began in December 2021, the court system processed a limited number of expunction requests annually through a petition process. For example, the North Carolina Administrative Office of the Courts processed 45,455 expunctions in fiscal years 2018-19, 2019-20, and 2020-21, according to the AOC’s 2023 Expunctions Report. But in the nine months the automatic expunction provision was operational, more than 400,000 charges were expunged.
“People were eligible for expungement over the last two years, but they didn’t get the expungement for one reason or the other. And so that’s why automation is so necessary, because if automation was running those million something cases would have been expunged through the automatic process,” said Webb.
The state’s transition to “eCourts” has made it easier for the court system to manage and store the massive number of cases. Senate Bill 565 also makes clear who can access expunged records. Only prosecutors, the individual whose record was expunged, or their attorney can access these records.
Currently, thanks in large part to the two-year suspension, there are more than 1 million cases eligible for expunction — a backlog that is expected to take as much as a year for the automatic process to work through. Individuals can still file a formal request to have their records expunged, but the process remains complex and difficult to negotiate for many individuals.
The post Cooper approves bill that preserves, updates automatic expunction law appeared first on NC Newsline .

author: Ximena Arochi
title: Sindicato de Notimex levanta su huelga tras el pago de indemnizaciones
text: Notimex Sindicato de Notimex levanta su huelga tras el pago de indemnizacionesLa Junta Federal de Conciliación y Arbitraje pagó las indemnizaciones a los trabajadores del Sindicato de Notimex, tras los cual, los periodistas y trabajadores de la agencia levantaron la huelga que duró tres años y 10 meses. CIUDAD DE MÉXICO (apro).- La Secretaría de Gobernación (Secgob) informó que la Junta Federal de Conciliación y Arbitraje realizó este viernes el pago de las indemnizaciones a los trabajadores del Sindicato Único de Trabajadores (SUT) de Notimex, tras los cual, los periodistas y trabajadores de la Agencia de Noticias del Estado concluyeron la huelga que duró tres años y 10 meses. En su cuenta de X, la Secgob publicó un comunicado en el que afirmó: “En cumplimiento a las instrucciones del presidente Andrés Manuel López Obrador, se realizó el pago correspondiente con pleno respeto a los derechos laborales de la organización sindical, de acuerdo con la Ley Federal del Trabajo”. A un costado del campamento que levantaron los huelguistas en avenida Baja California 200, en la alcaldía Cuauhtémoc, Adriana Urrea, secretaria general del SUT de Notimex, confirmó: “Hoy por la mañana se firmó ya el acuerdo entre Notimex, con la participación del Indep (Instituto para Devolverle al Pueblo lo Robado), que es el órgano litigador después de aceptarse el proceso de extinción, y obviamente ante las autoridades, para dar por terminada las relaciones primero colectivas y después individuales”. Aunque reconoció que el objetivo del sindicato era defender su fuente de trabajo y no el cierre de la agencia, agregó en conferencia: “Con esto se conjura la huelga en la agencia de noticias del Estado Mexicano”. Al ser cuestionada sobre si todos los trabajadores ya recibieron su indemnización, Urrea contestó: “Las liquidaciones ya se hicieron, de hecho esa fue condición para que nosotros pudiéramos levantar la huelga (...) no se iba a levantar campamento hasta que no se pagara al último trabajador”. Lo anterior también fue confirmado por la secretaria general del sindicato. Mientras sus compañeros enunciaron “que sube, que baja, su Notimex no se raja”, Adriana Urrea leyó un texto en el que apuntó que con el cierre de Notimex se termina con la fuente laboral de más de un centenar de trabajadores: “Bajo el pretexto de una supuesta corrupción en el Sut Notimex, Sanjuana Martines (exdirectora de Notimex) llegó a correr al personal, a violar los derechos de los trabajadores, a violar el contrato colectivo de trabajo, pues jamás demostró ante las autoridades tal corrupción”. Después exigió: “Que la dirección aclare públicamente dónde quedaron los millones de pesos que se otorgaron durante cinco años, cuando la agencia estuvo tres años y diez meses en huelga”. Durante la huelga, Sanjuana Martínez denunció que fue víctima de “terrorismo sindical”, al tiempo que los trabajadores la acusaban de abusos laborales. De acuerdo con el Sistema Nacional de Transparencia, Sanjuana Martínez recibió en 2019 un salario mensual bruto de 122 mil 512 pesos y un salario mensual neto de 86 mil 698 pesos, sin embargo, no muestra las percepciones salariales durante 2021, 2021, y 2021. El pasado 27 de septiembre, la exdirectora de la agencia de noticias publicó en su cuenta de la red X una foto con el presidente Andrés Manuel López Obrador: “Sostuve reunión con el presidente López obrador para preparar los últimos detalles del cierre de Notimex”. La posibilidad de un sindicato de industria Frente a los integrantes del sindicato, Urrea aseguró que seguirán en la lucha: “Volveremos y tendrán noticias nuestras porque esto no se acaba aquí”. Luego de sus palabras, los asistentes corearon la consigna: “Ni un paso atrás”. La secretaria general del SUT Notimex anunció que llevaron a asamblea la propuesta de transformar su organización en un sindicato de industria: “Esto significa que podremos dar acompañamiento y agrupar a trabajadores de otros medios de comunicación”. Argumentó que quieren aprovechar su experiencia, pues en el país el oficio de periodista es uno de los más precarizados, y detalló que están siendo asesorados de otros sindicatos que pasaron por dicho proceso de transformación, u otros que nacieron como sindicatos de industria. Además, adelantó que trabajan en la confirmación de una cooperativa, para hacer una nueva agencia de información que priorizará temas laborales y sindicales. Urrea llegó a dar su mensaje en compañía de José Luis Sánchez, director del departamento jurídico de la Secretaría de Trabajo y Previsión Social (STPS); Óscar Mendoza, miembro del departamento jurídico de la Secgob, y Carlos Mendoza, que encabeza el cuerpo jurídico de SUT Notimex. Otros sindicatos acudieron a la conferencia en muestra de apoyo, como el Sindicato de Trabajadores del Instituto Mexicano de Tecnología del Agua (Sitimta), Sindicato de Trabajadores de Prensa, Sindicato de Trabajadores del Instituto de Vivienda de la Ciudad de México (Astinvi), Sindicato de Telefonistas de la República Mexicana (STRM), la Federación Nacional de Sindicatos de la Banca de Desarrollo (Fenabad), por mencionar algunos. Al punto de las 16:40 horas, los periodistas y trabajadores del SUT Notimex comenzaron a retirar el campamento. El pasado 13 de diciembre, el Senado de la República aprobó la extinción de Notimex con 59 votos a favor, 44 en contra y 2 abstenciones. La medida fue impulsada por López Obrador, quien en abril pasado sostuvo que Notimex estaba por desaparecer, después de que operó durante 55 años.
